title: Adding singularity command group with recipe|build
body:
# Singularity Command

This is an early effort at a Singularity command, meaning that we create a
Singularity recipe (and can then optionall build a container) using it. It was fairly easy to put together with great example from https://github.com/spack/spack/pull/7204. This implementation is much simpler - we don't start any mirrors / volumes, we just scoot out a recipe and optionally build.

## The Command Group

Here is what the command group looks like. The user has the option to select
"recipe" or "build" subcommands. This extra grouping isn't essential, but provided
(as a design decision) so the final typed command is intuitive (reads like
a sentence).

```bash
$ bin/spack singularity -h
usage: spack singularity [-h] build|recipe ...

use singularity to build containers with spack packages

positional arguments:
  build|recipe
    recipe      generate a recipe
    build       generate a recipe and build it (required sudo)

optional arguments:
  -h, --help    show this help message and exit

```

For example, it's intuitive to ask for a recipe. 
Let's give a go to generate a recipe with a debian base, and install curl:

```bash
$ spack singularity recipe --from ubuntu:16.04 curl
==> Installing packages curl
==> Attempting to infer distro from base image...
==> Found distro ubuntu
==> Working directory created in /tmp/tmpfvp7wlfq
==> Writing recipe to /tmp/tmpfvp7wlfq/Singularity
==> sudo singularity build container.sif /tmp/tmpfvp7wlfq/Singularity
```

Here is the recipe generated from a template:

```
Bootstrap: docker
From: ubuntu:18.04

%environment
SPACK_ROOT=/home/spack
FORCE_UNSAFE_CONFIGURE=1
PATH="${PATH}:${SPACK_ROOT}/bin"
export SPACK_ROOT FORCE_UNSAFE_CONFIGURE PATH

%help
This is a spack container with packages curl

%post
SPACK_ROOT=/home/spack
FORCE_UNSAFE_CONFIGURE=1
PATH="${PATH}:${SPACK_ROOT}/bin"
export SPACK_ROOT FORCE_UNSAFE_CONFIGURE PATH

# Install basic system dependencies
apt-get update && \
    apt-get install -y git gcc g++ gfortran make bzip2 && \
    apt-get install -y patch file curl python gnupg2 xz-utils && \
    rm -rf /var/lib/apt/lists/*
    

# Install spack + set the mirror
mkdir -p $SPACK_ROOT
curl -s -L https://api.github.com/repos/spack/spack/tarball/develop \
    | tar xzC $SPACK_ROOT --strip 1

/home/spack/bin/spack install curl

%runscript
exec /home/spack/bin/spack "$@"
```

The final line is the command (instruction) to the user to build the container.
Let's do that.

```bash
$ sudo singularity build container.sif /tmp/tmpfvp7wlfq/Singularity
```

Then my container runs, exposing the spack entrypoint (and I can find curl).

```bash
$ singularity run container.sif 
usage: spack [-hkV] [--color {always,never,auto}] COMMAND ...

A flexible package manager that supports multiple versions,
configurations, platforms, and compilers.

These are common spack commands:

query packages:
  list                  list and search available packages
  info                  get detailed information on a particular package
  find                  list and search installed packages

build packages:
  install               build and install packages
  uninstall             remove installed packages
  spec                  show what would be installed, given a spec

environments:
  env                   manage virtual environments
  view                  project packages to a compact naming scheme on the filesystem.

modules:
  load                  add package to environment using `module load`
  module                manipulate module files
  unload                remove package from environment using `module unload`

create packages:
  create                create a new package file
  edit                  open package files in $EDITOR

system:
  arch                  print architecture information about this machine
  compilers             list available compilers

optional arguments:
  -h, --help            show this help message and exit
  -k, --insecure        do not check ssl certificates when downloading
  -V, --version         show version number and exit
  --color {always,never,auto}
                        when to colorize output (default: auto)

more help:
  spack help --all       list all commands and options
  spack help <command>   help on a specific command
  spack help --spec      help on the spec syntax
  spack docs             open http://spack.rtfd.io/ in a browser
vanessa@vanessa-ThinkPad-T460s:~/Documents/Dropbox/Code/Python/spack$ singularity run container.sif find curl
==> 1 installed package
-- linux-ubuntu18.04-x86_64 / gcc@7.4.0 -------------------------
curl@7.63.0
```

That's basically it - it's the simplest implementation I could think of, meaning
I don't bring in any special libraries (Singularity Python, HPC Container Maker, etc.)
The user can switch recipe --> build (and use sudo) to do the same process, but
building the container at the end.

```
$ sudo bin/spack singularity build --from ubuntu:16.04 curl
```

For the interested reader, here is an asciinema that shows the recipe generation
and then build (to confirm that the example at least works!)

[asciinema](https://asciinema.org/a/244183?speed=3)


## Discussion

### Should containers be kept with spack?

Given that we have a build command, is there some avenue for containers to be "a thing"
that spack installs? For example, instead of having `opt/spack/linux-ubuntu16.04-x86_64/`
We might dump a container into `opt/spack/containers/singularity` and then name based on
the packages installed (the specs.)


### Entrypoint examples?
Having spack as the entrypoint makes sense for discovery of what is installed. But 
what is the way I would specify running curl (or any installed package) via the spack
entrypoint? We should have these examples provided (by default) in the container
help.

### Alpine / busybox base

<s>We need to have this as an option - I'll just start working on it (need to test
the dependencies for spack) and then give it a go (not sure if spack supports these
bases, but I'll find out!)</s>

alpine is added. I'm not sure we need busybox, but others can comment.

### Custom environment / labels / files

What labels would be useful to add (by default?) Is it a valid use case to want
to add some other set of environment variables, labels, files, or commands?

### Reproducibility

The "reproducibility raccoon" in me wants to (given that the user builds the container
for storage with spack) also keep the recipe, especially if we open up avenues to
add further customization other than installing packages.

### Customize entrypoint?

Any potential use case of a user wanting the entrypoint to not be spack?
I would err on not providing this because we lose information / metadata about
the container that spack can provide. But it could be wanted.

### Don't generate recipe?
Arguably, if we don't need to build, the recipe can be printed to screen.
I am assuming that the average user generating a recipe wants to keep it,
so I wrote to file. However it would be one extra step to pipe into a recipe file,
in case that it's wanted. I would say this is a reasonable start unless someone
has huge issue.

### Check if Singularity not installed

Does spack do this when I create the executable (or do I need to?)

Signed-off-by: Vanessa Sochat <vsochat@stanford.edu>
